There's no antifragile. The mind can get stronger, bigger, but it is still mind and can be fragile.  In Ananda Marga we say that the mind develops through "clash and cohesion", which is basically the same as the "post traumatic growth" mentioned in the video. But we (mostly) don't look for clash, physical or emotional, or trauma(!), but it comes naturally. And for us spirituality not just "finding meaning and purpose", but it is a practical thing, well explained in our philosophy. As "spirit" or "consciousness" is perfect in itself, spirituality essentially means the psycho-spiritual process or sadhana or tantrik meditation where we direct our mind inwards, towards consciousness. That results in a very profoundly healing, cohesive process, which at the same time incites more clashes or sources of unhappiness on our way! That also gives balance and perspective to the sources or happiness and unhappiness in our lives. And sadhana and helping others selflessly are the best way to make the mind stronger.

I suppose live miserably to become antifragile. But that doesn't sound like a good goal. You need enough controlled misery to build some strength to get through in life. Alternatively, just carry on in life, and take each misery as a growth opportunity. No need to create artificial misery to build strength in order to bear more misery and build more strength and so on. The real goal is to reframe our miseries, detach from them and look at them as hurdles thrown at us to cross.

I would refer to this as "PTG training" or "antifragility training". The idea is to grow your resilience and toughness by exposing yourself to progressive levels of trauma that you can handle in a relatively controlled environment. There are certain sports or physical activities which I think contribute to PTG, by being extremely challenging or demanding, even painful, without risking your health. Professional guidance and adequate physical preparation are fundamental, but there is a lot that comes from within yourself, which I think has a lot to do with your happiness skills.  The first one I can think of is rock climbing. You can start at a very easy level which almost everybody can try, but it always takes you to situations which appear impossible to overcome. Only by trying and trying again, defeating your frustration and improving yourself, you come to realize that you can actually do things that you thought were impossible.  Hiking and mountain-biking add some elements of risk. You can get injured for real and experience real pain. So it is especially important to be properly equipped and trained at your level. Being able to get back on the bike after a fall is as close as I can imagine to PTG. I should just insist this is not about being reckless. You really have to be disciplined to work at your level and avoid unnecessary risks that can hamper your progress.  Playing the guitar, as harmless as it is, can be quite frustrating and painful. Your fingers really hurt and the retribuition of playing well takes a lot of practice and patience.  You may come with similar explanations for other sports or activities, such as tennis or golf. From these examples it appears that the primary area of action is Physical, then Emotional. It's hard to imagine a connection with the other three, but there must be ways to work on those too.

For me, when quitting smoking back in 2002, and then quitting drinking in 2020, it involved learning to examine and embrace my entire spectrum of emotions and feelings unafraid. Even unlearning to label them as negative is really key, because labeling as negative causes avoidance and pain. There are times when we can consciously decide that a given line of inner dialogue or self-representation is unproductive, and that's good for us, but there are other times when we reactively reject the examination of a state of inner turmoil or pain and if we only thought to investigate further, we might find it contained hidden gems â€” that it contains its own cure.

Exercise is huge. Especially exercise that continually explores new ways of moving and developing mobility, strength, and flexibility along previously untried lines. The physical development creates mental and emotional analogues.

Live life as it comes upon you, do what you need to do and still to a routine to survive.  Pursue the most optimal routine for all of your goals and don't get attached.  Continue on your road towards your goals and don't look to past to long for things that are gone.   The past is gone and cannot be changed, the present is what will make the future a better time to be alive.   Grow through the challenges of existence, work and do everything as if you were already dead, as if everything had been already been lost.   Work as if your dreams are unattainable and work to achieve them all the same, work as if you had failed already and still worry more about becoming a better you rather than worrying about how you will deal with the future, deal with the present and focus on that.   Keep yourself as busy as possible and keep good relationships with people, hold yourself accountable for everything you do or don't.   Do more than it is necessary, it is never enough.   Work yourself to dead and pursue that which you want to achieve relentlessly never stopping.   Dedicate your present life to what you want your future to be, don't let yourself doubt about being able to achieve it or not, that's why you must work as if it was possible but expect nothing in return because it is already something you lost and can never get back.   This mindset will make you focus on becoming the person who could be X, even if attaining X is impossible now, this will make become the ideal you and if things do work out for you in the end then that will make it all the better.  Worst case scenario you end becoming who wanted to be in a place where you shouldn't be.  The logic is that when you are that person that should be at X place, then people will acknowledge you and society as well, at some point you will be able to reach out to X dream and make it a reality, because you already became the ideal person to make X a reality.

I was horrifically depressed since childhood. It was relentless. I assumed it would ultimately end me somehow. About twelve years ago I randomly accepted the offer from a friend of a few doses of mushrooms. I did them two consecutive nights alone. First night was pretty mild. The second night? Wow. I saw my depression from every angle, realized much. Next day: depression totally gone. Never came back, never coming back. It's like it's a forest far away I can remember, and could probably find again with enough effort, but it has zero impact on anything in my life or mind. They honestly saved my life and improved it immensely. I never did them again, either. I wish there was a good, organized way to administer them to people who would benefit from them

My notes:  Antifragility - Anti-fragile system = when pressures is added the systems grows (f.e. muscles) - On a psychological level = PTG (post traumatic growth)  - PTG means growing stronger as a result of pressure/ stress (growing from hardship) - The happiness paradox: happiness is a good thing but valuing it as a good thing/ pushing it can be problematic (can lead to depression) - resolve by indirect pursue: SPIRE model (creates happiness altogether) - SPIRE = spiritual, physical, intellectual, relational & emotional wellbeing whereas: - Spirituality = finding a sense of meaning & purpose in life, work & home - Physical = worst enemy is stress, recovery from stress is required  - Intellectual = curiosity, asking questions, deeply engaging with material (art, text, nature) - Relational = quality time with loved ones is the Nr. 1 predictor of happiness â€”> the quality of our relationships is the most important factor for antifragility  - Emotional = embracing negative emotions, gratitude  - Happiness is a lifelong journey, not a pursuitÂ   Youâ€™re welcome:)

Summary / Notes:   Resilience 1.0 = when you put pressure on a system, after pressure is lifted, it comes back to its original position form  Anti-fragility = Resilience 2.0 ( If you put pressure on a system, when lifted, it grows bigger and stronger ) Eg: Muscular system when you workout  Anti-fragility on psychological level is called PTG means Post Traumatic Growth ( Opposite of PTSD which means post traumatic stress disorder )  Happiness is a good thing but valuing it as a only good thing is a problematic.  Happiness Paradox = People who make happiness as a goal, leads them to less happiness  It needs to be pursued indirectly through SPIRE MODEL to trigger anti fragile system and wholebeing   Spiritual = Finding a sense of meaning and purpose in life, at work and at home Physical = Being stress free and be able to recover from stress  Intellectual = Be curios and deeply engaging with material  Relational = Quality time with people we care about and who care about us Emotional = Embrace emotional and cultivate pleasurable ones ( it can be done through gratitude = when we appreciate the good in our life, we have more of it )  I do not believe things always happen for the best, but I believe we can make the best of what happens.

The speaker introduces the idea that experiencing painful emotions is a natural part of life and an important aspect of happiness studies. They discuss antifragility, which refers to systems that grow stronger under pressure, such as muscles or post-traumatic growth. Pursuing happiness directly can lead to less happiness, so the speaker suggests an indirect approach by focusing on the SPIRE model: spiritual, physical, intellectual, relational, and emotional well-being. They emphasize the importance of finding meaning, managing stress, curiosity, quality relationships, and embracing both painful and pleasurable emotions. Happiness is seen as a lifelong journey where one learns to make the best of what happens.

It always amazes me how the happiness "specialists" haven't cracked it yet, even though it's pretty easy: Your body has desires (desire to eat, to fuck, to be liked, to learn, to survive, to rest, etc). The desire creates tension in the form of emotions (hunger, anxiety, boredom, etc). Desiring something a lot gives your mind emotional pain. Satisfying the desire gives you pleasure/ happiness. Simple. Bonus knowledge: why do people who are desiring happiness become less happy? Because desire creates pain. Simple. Explaining: In order to be happy, one must satisfy the desire. If you desire to drink water, you'll only be happy after drinking the water. If you desire to be happy, it's as if you're telling yourself: I'm not happy now, but I'll be happy after I become happy, so I want to become happy. Do you see how this line of thought doesn't make one happy? It makes you believe you're unhappy, which makes you unhappy, it creates a desire, which makes you unhappy, and it doesn't give you any pratical possible step to achieve it. If you want water, you know you can just go get some water. But you can't just go get happiness. Happiness depends on satisfying a desire, but your desire is to be happy, so you're creatinga greater distance between yourself and happiness. It's like a horse that walks forward to get a carrot, but the carrot is hanging from a fishing pole that is connected to the horse's back. Every time it moves forward, the carrot moves forward. The more you desire happiness, the more pain you get, the more pain you get, the more you desire happiness, which makes you in greater pain, which makes you desire more, etc. Bonus bonus knowledge: Bhudda had already figured out this a long time ago. Desire is pain. Letting go of desire sets you free of pain: nirvana. That's why when you're meditating you're supposed to focus only on the present, so you don't focus on desiring things in the future. And if your mind wanders off into desiring something, you're not supposed to be angry at yourself. Because that's desiring to have perfect control, which gives you pain. Just relax and go back to focused attention again. Meditating lets you let go of a lot of accumulated desires. They'll go back to growing after you stop meditating, but while the're still low your mind and body can rest better.

There is a false narrative that a happy life means being happy all the time. But in reality learning to embrace painful emotions is an important part of a happy life. And the study of painful emotions is an important part of the field of happiness studies.  Resilience 1.0 is when we put pressure on an system, that object goes back to it's original form. Antifragility takes this idea a step further: Resilience 2.0 is: you put pressure on a system it actually grows bigger, stronger. We see antifragile system all around us and within us. For example when we go to the gym we're putting pressure on our muscles, what happens as a result, we actually grow stronger.  On a psychological level you know what thats called? Post traumatic growth. So where post traumatic stress disorder PTSD is about breaking down, post traumatic growth is about growing stronger. As a result of pressure of stress.  We know from research that people who say to themselves: "happiness is important for me, I want to pursue it."   Those individuals actually end up being less happy. In fact, they're more likely to experience depression. Happiness is a good thing, but. Valuing it as a good thing is problematic. So what do we do? The way to solve this is to pursue happiness indirectly. Gratitude is the mother of all virtues, when we appreciate the goodness in our life we have more of it. Happiness is a life long journey and knowing that we can have realistic rather than unrealistic expectations about what is possible.  I do not think that things necessarily happen for the best. However, we can learn to make the best of things that happen.

Not the original commenter but something that helped me with self confidence was -  1. Stop caring about what people think about you.  Think about it, how much time do YOU spend thinking about other people, not much I believe, but you are thinking about yourself most of the time. That's it, everyone is thinking about themselves, not you.  2. Try setting goals for everyday, however small it is but make the goal a part of bigger picture. Like learning a new language, everyday set a small goal of learning about the language, watch content in that language, just small goals everyday. Consistency is better than intensity, doing a little everyday adds up.  Just my 2 cents and also become curious about new things and learn about them, keep yourself busy and you will stop thinking about other people.  Hope it helps, âœŒï¸

He's right. Things do not always happen "for the best". Sure, you've become stronger, but would you re-experience the pain of the loss of the ones you loved most in exchange for your newfound strength? Of course not. But the pain is inevitable, so might as well work on overcoming it, instead of trying to deny it doesn't exist or will never happen to you again. And then you can employ your unwanted but newfound strength in new and novel ways.

Anti-fragility is to realize I may climb out on the ledge again and desire to cast myself into the abyss. But there's a 98% chance I'll climb back in and join the race again. Duration: these trips to the ledge may happen once or twice a year, or twice this week, or not again for a decade or two.

Tal Ben-Shahar, a happiness studies teacher and author, discusses the concept of antifragility, which refers to the idea that some systems, both physical and psychological, can become stronger and more resilient when subjected to stress or pressure. He suggests that the study of happiness should focus on what conditions can be put in place to increase the likelihood of growing from hardship, and introduces the SPIRE model (spiritual, physical, intellectual, relational, and emotional well-being) as a way to trigger the antifragile system and promote happiness indirectly. He emphasizes that happiness is more than just pleasure and that it is a lifelong journey. He also suggests that embracing painful emotions and cultivating the emotion of gratitude are important for emotional well-being.

Way too much emphasis is put on happiness........ It would be much better to concentrate on expectations......... Higher the expectations more likelihood that the a person will not be happy with life, or put it in more constructive way: more likely that the person will not be satisfied with life...... Instead of seeking happiness it might be more rewarding to look and attain the attitude of content...... To be content is something that can be attained within the mind, it is not external, unlike the happiness that almost in all its forms depends to external conditions, or the navigation of the external conditions........ One can be fragile and yet be content........ Fragility is a fertile ground for creativity......... For an artistic person becoming antifragile would mean the death of creative endeavour....

Why are we even entertaining the term "happy life"? We shouldn't bother trying to redefine a "happy life". There's nothing wrong with the description, in fact we should keep it intact so we can point to it as a bad idea. Balance and peace in varied circumstances is how I describe what we are really after. I'm sure we can come up with other descriptions, but "happy" isn't a part of any of them. That word has been tainted for a long long time by forceful attempts at living a poorly conceived fantasy.

Â @nia2088Â  From my take, I think it's saying to not be afraid of doing hard things. (best summary is the last bit if it's TL:DR)  So like for the Spirtual part, he mentions having a purpose in the morning. While this can be something long term like build up a great career, it can also be small things like cleaning a bedroom and then watering some plants (so assigning yourself a task to build up some urgency). While doing this, you also have to consider the physical part, which he said was to do with stress. So when you take time off, you may still be worrying about things or that you're being productive. But what he is saying is to treat it like a productive thing and that you should treat it like a job in itself and actually completely try to de-stress.  by doing these steps you are breaking down the task's that you would view as hard or stressful (especially if you're depressed or neurodivergent) and learning how to break it down and not chase instant gratification, but learn how to enjoy and balance the stress of doing the task's you need to do.  It's essentially incorporating Frankl's logotherapy, where he suggests we all need a purpose, so instead of trying to find something that will make us happy, Frankl suggests we need something to work towards and that in turn what will bring us happiness. (But this builds upon it, by providing steps as to how to achieve this)

Your entire philosophy is predicated on a falsehood. Humans aren't an anti-fragility system. They're actually super-fragile. They get more fragile with each test of their resilience. Muscles do grow when you destroy them with laborious efforts, but the new muscles individually aren't as strong as the old ones AND now they require a lot more resources to maintain. The system has gotten MORE fragile, not less.  You can malign the psychopath all you like, but they were born to a world that grinds humans into dust and they are simply an evolution of mankind that is harder to grind down. If humans want to become "less fragile" then they need to stop trying to dominate the world and learn how to co-exist with it - avoiding tests of their resilience not by finding more ways to attack it.

I think the sunlight analogy is almost perfect but thereÂ´s something missing. Even after you break up light into different colors, it can still damage your eyes if you look at it directly. So the key is, as explained in the presentation, to look at it indirectly. That is not looking at sun light directly, but looking at its reflection from other objects, which basically attenuates it. Then you can handle light even without splitting it into different colors. Splitting it into different colors, to study its composition in more detail, completes the analogy as a final step.  This might also provide some insight into the possibility of using controlled PSG to improve our resilience, toughness and "antifragility". Instead of exposing yourself to fully traumatic real-life events, you practice with some relatively challenging and moderately traumatic events, from which you know you can recover easily and grow. It appears to me that this controlled PTG taps mainly into the physical and emotional elements of the SPIRE model, but there could be ways to put "PTG training" in the other elements as well.

Of course, those who feel happy would not seek to find happiness, while those who recently faced hardships that broke them will seek it at all cost. This is why I think people who seek it will end up being less happy, naturally. If you never experienced something that was the complete opposite of happiness, you will never value it in the same way and find it natural.  In the same way, people get more curious if they feel more secure, and once they feel insecure or down, they won't be able to be open towards new experiences and learn in the same way. Also focusing on one thing deeply might be impossible for people in a bad mental situation. Also, those people tend to try to get away from others, as they feel overwhelmed by the social pressure of functioning. This is something temporary. In phases of life where you can live in a path you got to pave, you will grow, while if there is no secure path, you will just need to survive.  Basically, this goes about it the wrong way. It is showing symptoms of happiness as causes of happiness.

There's no happiness without sadness. Everything in life is in balance. It's a matter of seeing  the balance. I was partially paralyzed for 3 years and was bedridden with GBS. People around me would see the big picture of me being bedridden and assumed my life was sad, depressing and all around terrible. From my perspective, I  wasn't in a functional body but there were so many things I was grateful for in my mind. Not being in intense pain, having friends around me, living in a house and not homeless, being able to eat everyday, etc. There are people who were as sick as I was and they were homeless, in pain with no food. In turn, I couldn't assume they were completely  depressed and sad either because maybe they had a spark of hope, love and positivity inside of them that keeps them going.

Always been told I'm so negative and having the wrong outlook on life. But yet, here I am, feeling rather content and grateful over plenty of things in my life.  Telling the brutal truth about a situation, isn't the same as being negative or feeling hopelessness and depression either. If one aspect of my life is currently shit, it is effing shit! Doesn't automatically mean that all of my life is shit, though. Quite the opposite.  I personally don't want to focus my efforts chasing something which won't happen anyway. I want to be smart, not foolish. I don't want to put all of my marbles in one bag. Like "if I could just get to x, I'll be happy". That's not realistic, and you risk missing out on all the great stuff that's all around you.   Now, to give some context. I do have worries, and feel emotional pain and sorrow on a weekly basis. Which is fine. As I won't let it dominate me, or take up a lot of my daily time. I discovered a few years ago, that you actually do have the ability to decide, that you're not a puppet forced to go along as I previously sort of thought. (Don't read too much into this. Clinical depression is definitely a serious and real condition. Sometimes outside help from professionals are needed). The lifestyle I love and cherish, got yanked right out from under my feet 1,5yrs ago. I'm now battling horrible postcovid symptoms, in a drawn out marathon war.  I haven't had the best of luck in my life, and carries a lot of luggage with me. Some which are PTSD, most of these are luckily closed chapters of my life now. The postcovid entered my life at the absolutely worst possible timing. Finances are also near, in ruins.  Long story short, there's a lot of hardship in the past, in the present and no doubt in the future. But I'm not depressed. I don't feel unhappy. I find reasons everyday to be grateful, despite the hardships. I honestly recon that I'll have a much better chance dealing with the postcovid, and the other pressing threats in my life, if I'm keeping a level head. Drawing strength from all the happy and grateful moments I experience, daily. I'm genuinely feeling mentally strong and sturdy. I guess antifragile is another word to describe that feeling.

The most dangerous lie one can believe is that of there being something to attain that would satisfy one for the rest of one's life. The moment you believe that lie you you create two common negative thought patterns: - I need to work to get something. Be that happiness or something material that you attribute happiness to. And.. - Happiness is something you find.  Happiness isn't anything you find or gain. It's a certain psycho-physiological state within you. But because you believe these two lies you have thus given control over that state to external factors. Suddenly everything around you determines your emotional state, your happiness. That's why you think a career or family or materialistic things will make you happy. But why shouldn't you be in charge of your own emotions? If you don't take back control, you'll run around in circles chasing after that one thing or achievement that'll finally make you happy. But nothing can make you happy but yourself. You're in charge of regulating your emotional states, if you decide to let your subconscious regulate it for you based on really stupid things you taught it to attribute it to, then well good luck. But none of this matters because neither good nor bad emotions are fundamentally good or bad. Just do whatever, but don't get stuck in lies and viscous cycles of stress and frustration. It doesn't have to be that way.

Are there good and bad rocks? Does the wave of an ocean look good or bad? Is life itself good or bad? It's whatever you tell yourself it is. That means, without your judgement, everything is fundamentally neutral. So if you experience something bad, it's on you. "But rape and murder are obviously bad". Well, in that case almost all living animals are pretty bad. Societal standards are not a base line for truth. They're our collective choice to judge things a certain way for no other reason than to create a common ground for us. So that we don't act like animals and function productively together. We limit ourselves for that purpose, not because anything is actually right or wrong. As such we're putting survival and comfort above truth. We live in an illusion. And yet we strive for truth. How are you gonna find truth if you're also the one judging truth from lie? You never can, unless you stop judging everything and start being open for everything. To do that you need to unlearn everything you think you know about life. Because it's all just taught to you by limited people that have obviously never found an answer to life's questions. But they're good at blindly believing things. Like religion, science, common sense, morals and societal standards. Do you have absolute proof that all of those are fundamentally real and true? Of course not, because any proof you have would be blind belief. And you know it. If you want truth, get rid of the lies you're believing. Not saying there's anything wrong with society or morals or having your own views and values. But it'd be a shame if you spent your life suffering and running in circles because you never see the illusionary nature of knowledge.

Life is an active and ongoing rebuke of entropy -- the law of thermodynamics that says all things end up cold, dark, and dead (to paraphrase). That you're even reading this comment is amazing. Your complex brain shouldn't even exist. But life finds a way. And, oh, does it.  So if we find happiness in meaning, what is the meaning of life? Well, we just covered that in the first paragraph: the meaning of life is to tell entropy to fuck off. Life is about caring. Because taking care of something is the opposite of entropy. First, we care for ourselves, because if you don't eat, sleep, take a shower, and brush your teeth, you won't be much of an entropy fighter. Then we can take care of others: family, friends, pets, strangers, our planet. That's where happiness resides. And we're allowed to take breaks. Please do. But don't give up until you have to. Because there's plenty of time for the universe to be cold, dark, and dead. But for an amazing, shining moment, you can care, and have meaning, and be happy.

Happiness is the result of removing all suffering from one's life. The time-tested experts for doing this are the Buddhists, who developed the "Eightfold Path to the Release From All Suffering" about 2,600 years ago. This Path was take from even more ancient Yogic principals for relieving suffering. The Path is a set of logical suggestions based on scientific "cause and effect" observations.  *Any person who wants to be happy by being free from all suffering can try these suggestions in their own life to see for themselves if they are valid. The person is free to modify and adapt them to the current time and culture. **The Path is a never-ending process, a person starts at the beginning and works their way to the end; and then starts at the beginning again. I'm a 65 year old American man. I agree. I've been pushing myself most of my life and have slowly been increasing the push throughout my life. I'm not sure if increasing the push is required to keep the benefits. I got on this path when I joined the US Army out of high school. I did it just to get money for college. Young dumb kid I didn't really think it was a big deal, and really it wasn't. But I saw how much it changed me, made me stronger in all ways. Stringer, not strong. So I just kind of kept looking for things, choices that made me more.  Now I look back on my life and wow, pretty intense imo. I retired at 45 but that just gave me more options. That didn't mean spending more money. For the past 15 years my total spend has averaged $600/mo. That's part of the path. What can I do without AND be happier.  I'm not sure "happy" is the correct term. Content might be better. Sometimes I do get so happy I do a little dance. Nothing particular, just realizing what a great life I've created for myself. You would not be impressed. Going for a 2 hour walk here in Phoenix, mid day, summer, 110F to buy groceries so carrying 20lbs of groceries 2.5 miles back home. I never carry water. And I love it. I do it nearly everyday. Insane? There's the rub. It's impossible I think to convey the concept. It has to be stumbled into maybe. Certainly living the path is the only way to understand it. And I assume maybe many people just aren't built for it.  Today I'm getting my central Phoenix ready to sell and I'll be moving to SE Asia. Can't say I'm looking forward to it. I love my house here in Phoenix. Virtually no mosquitoes, sunny nearly everyday, can walk everywhere. Very comfortable. But then I hated moving to Phoenix. That's the paradox. I learned how to be happy in Phoenix. Learning how to be happy is a great skill to have. I can be happy standing in line at the DMV.

I think it's more that if you "pursue" happiness, you are therefore very AWARE of the fact that you don't have it.   If all your focus is on what you are lacking, you will be unhappy and desperate for that happiness.   If you focus on what you do have and what you can control now, you will find meaning in your life. Happiness will come and go depending on what happens in your life. But being able to have gratitude and build on what you do have is the key.  Just don't focus on what you dont have. Don't pursue happiness.

Â @kaiserwilhelm3680Â  I had a pretty severe depression (although more situational than clinical I think), and what helped me to dig out was to realize most of my unhappiness was in focusing on what I lacked, rather than what I had. So, essentially, cultivating gratitude, but more than that, just a basic acceptance of what is--not that things can't change, but just that they can't be different in this very moment. On paper, it seems like it would make it worse, but accepting what is (i.e., more present), I wasn't focused on what was gone, or seemingly impossible, or on the unknowns of the future. Nothing had noticeably changed in my life except how I looked at it, but that changed everything. There is nothing wrong with right now. It is because what has happened has already  happened. There is nothing to worry about in the past because it can't be altered. There is nothing to worry about in the future either, because it's not here yet. You can plan things, but you can only actually do them right now. The kid sounds like a real blessing, but don't forget to give yourself what you need, too. If you  can afford it, and you haven't already, get some help from a therapist too, or even a psychiatrist if need be. And take inspiration from your son's natural curiosity and simple joy and allow yourself to emulate that as best you can. So much of it seems to be a matter of just getting out of your own head.

The problem with pursuing happiness is our understanding/interpretion of it. Mostly it is interpreted as a period of or even permanent euphoria.  But happiness isn't that. A better interpretion for it would be a state of contendedness, being content with how things are. So in other words a lack of longing/desire/pursuit.  Pursuit of happiness is an inherent contradicition.

Happiness is a myth. I've worked hard in my life to achieve things that are difficult and take months or years of effort to happen. Those things only made me feel happy and fulfilled for a matter of days, or sometimes only hours. When I look back at my past accomplishments, I don't really feel anything. I just want to focus on the next long-term goal, even though I know from experience that reaching my next big goals won't make me feel happy long-term either. Living is truly hopeless. Things that make me feel instantly happy, only make me happy for some minutes. Things that require long-term effort (weeks, months or years) only make me happy for some days. Not doing anything makes me miserable. Working on my goals makes me miserable.

Aristotelian virtue ethics is by far the best approach there is to living a good life. Forming good and rational habits is the key in virtue ethics. That's what the virtues are; rationally acquired habits.   A lot of the things said in this video echo Aristotles ideas, mainly the thing towards the end about happiness being more than just pleasure, and true happiness being continuous. Aristotle, being Greek, used the word 'eudaimonia' to describe what most translators call 'happiness', although the best translation I've found is 'flourishing', based on the contents of Aristotles writings on eudaimonia.   I'd recommend anybody to learn more about Aristotles philosophy. If you're interested, let me know and I'll share some good material for you to check out.

Just a caveat on how correlation doesnâ€™t imply causality: people who value happiness might do so BECAUSE they donâ€™t have it, while those who donâ€™t value happiness might do so BECAUSE they already have it (and perhaps take it for granted). Think of someone who strives for physical health because theyâ€™re out of shape, while people who are already fit might value other pursuits. You wouldnâ€™t tell the unhealthy to stop pursuing healthiness because itâ€™ll make them less healthy! (as long as theyâ€™re pursuing health in a healthy way, like exercising and eating well, and not in a toxic way, like eating disorders)  Similarly, we canâ€™t conclude from his evidence that valuing happiness CAUSES you to become unhappy (unless the studies in question did something to explicitly test for causation). Become antifragile? Stop being so sensitive?`What...? Why? So that you could fake your life away being something you're not?  True happiness can only be attained by being honest. And they who deny themselves and who they are, by that extension, can never reach the same degree of happiness as those who live with who they really are, even if it's sometimes very painful.  Having said that, I do very much agree with the initial premise on the video. Pain is a crucial part of life, as it is one of our core guidance systems. It is not supposed to be hailed as the only system by which you adhere to, but at the same time, it's supposed to be listened to and taken to account in the big picture of making personal decisions of all scales.  Contrasts like pain and pleasure compliment each other,. I have noticed this very acutely in my personal life, whether it's physical hardships like taking ice cold showers and working your ass off in a physical job while sleeping in the woods nearby, or dodging dangerous situations and having fear of death as your companion whenever you go to sleep all vulnerable out there. I only started to value living indoors more after living in the woods with only a hammock and some basic equipment to keep me from the elements. I started to value my money more after being in debt AND broke. I started to value my time more after working 12-hour night shifts with no real life outside work.  When you apply these kind of things to PSYCHE and SOUL though, it's different from applying them to some machine. Less streamlined and less straightforward. Peoples' psyches can be broken more easily than they think, at least that was the case with me, and I know stories like that. You need to give the person basic tools to help themselves with and allow them to help themselves when it's time for them to do that.  Also let me point an obvious simplification or fallacy if you will, that the guy in this video said: "When we go to gym and lift weights, our muscles grow stronger." You left a crucial core part out of that bro. The muscle growth actually happens when you rest and recover, because the muscle IS BEING BROKEN at the gym and you regenerate that afterwards with nutrition, relaxation and sleep, and you regenerate a bit extra because your body is intelligent and knows to prepare for that kinda ordeal because it has become a reality for it. But the crucial part is, you trust your body, listen to your body, and LET IT REST AND RECOVER, regenerate.  People. Don't just swallow anything this guy on the video or I or anyone else regurgitate, or even if a research paper claims it a scientific fact. DO YOUR OWN FIELD RESEARCH so you can't be fooled by anybody. That gives your worldviews a different kind of resilience, so you don't have to go from religion to atheism to agnosticism etc just to find out it's not really what fulfills you in a truly healthy way.

Iâ€™m turning 20 this month, and over the last year or so Iâ€™ve come to realize that I honestly enjoy and find comfort in sadness. Itâ€™s the way you manage that sadness that makes a difference. Like reading a good book or watching a show or a movie that makes you cry. That feels good, right? Thatâ€™s how Iâ€™ve started thinking of sadness from my every day life too.  I like and accept all emotions as long as theyâ€™re handled with care. Even happiness can be handled wrong and have a negative impact. For example, because youâ€™re so happy you might ignore small issues that have been bothering you for a long time because at the time they donâ€™t really impact you, and so you donâ€™t bother to work on fixing any of it, which later might become a problem.  I think of it a bit like in Buddhism. Accepting oneâ€™s emotions and not trying to change them. Because if you constantly try to change how you feel youâ€™ll just never feel satisfied, because constant happiness just isnâ€™t possible. But enjoying, or at the very least getting content with other emotions as well is possible.  Iâ€™ve also found that itâ€™s better to focus on physical changes you can make in life rather than emotional ones as those are changes you can actually control.  I can go on regular walks every week, and that may or may not make me feel happy, but either way it will get me in a better physical shape, and it is a form of change even if it isnâ€™t an emotional one. Realizing and accepting that fact helps.   It also helps letting go of the image that sadness and anger etc are negative emotions. If someone is treating you unfairly anger is important. Crying is also not negative as it releases toxins.  So many times friends of mine might say â€œIâ€™m cryingâ€ and my other friends respond with â€œnooo donâ€™t cryâ€ because sadness is seen as negative. However, I always say â€œgood. Cry. Release those toxinsâ€ because rejecting sadness just makes it hurt more. Itâ€™s that feeling of hopelessness because you canâ€™t change how you feel that often is the worst, so once you stop trying to change your emotions it immediately becomes a bit easier.   Iâ€™m obviously not saying to give up, but simply accept and welcome all emotions. Trying to push it away only causes strain.   Sorry for the rant lol. I just wanted to share my thoughts.

Â @MrJiggerGÂ  the thing most older people don't understand is that advice, which wasn't asked for, is not always the best advice. My generation mostly learned to only give advice when we're asked for, and that is actually just kore respectful. Most people who come to others to complain mainly want to vent, and hearing advice can be difficult, because the advisers often don't have access to some details about the situation and give advice that can't be practically used because of that and because those details that the speaker may even have omitted may influence the effectiveness of that advice. If you want my take on it, from the people from the older generations I've spoken to, and I've spoken to quite a few, it was the easiest and even most useful (if we are talking about usefulness) to talk to those who didn't immediately give advice and just encouraged me to figure it out myself, unless I specifically asked for advice, and usually the good listeners had far better advice than people who started giving advice as soon as I said something, because they wanted to share their wisdom. I'm a teacher, and this principle is my motto: help, but only if I see students struggle, but it is far better to let students figure things out themselves. So, it's true about life too. As for upbringing, the ideal variant would be where parents set up some learning situations where making mistakes won't hurt the child, and discuss the situation afterwards. Not just "teach them about life whenever possible". So, my main point is that most older people need to learn to listen instead of interrupting because they have something to say. That "something" may very well change if they only finish listening. That's what a lot of people do and that is what deters younger people from listening to older people's advice, although usually good listeners win that respect later on

Use of inappropriate metaphors is dissimulation = deception. NO one  looks at the sun, because eyes are made to function at lower light levels, and looking at sun blinds one, PERMANENTLY. Happiness is NOT a "sun", just ask those who close  their eyes in orgasm. EVERY sensory input is EVALUATED by our associative brain - there is NO 'spiritual"; what there IS, is stimulation of  hormones, hormones that self-signal likelihood of satisfaction, exhaustion, and satiation. Hormones and neurotransmitters that signal depression, rest, avoidance  of injury as we associate present with remembered events, occur because = USEFUL in preventing injury or loss. It's OK to experience exultation, a hormonal effect -- but there is NO "spook" spirit out there. it's YOU, experiencing motivation, persistence , expectation of tangible reward, satiation, exhaustion, and body/brain demanding rest for anabolic renewal. Garbage metaphors signal intent to delude. If you want happiness, exhaust yourself physically, as depression is MOST correlated with lack of physical action. We are Animals, evolved to MOVE. Plants are evolved to use sunlight to turn CO2 and water and a few other molecules into food, while we are rewarded by successful foraging, chasing it.

0:06 "Psychopaths" - or if we are going to be scientific - people with antisocial personality disorder, feel no empathy, but they do feel painful emotions. Hatred is one of them. Frustration is another. Ted Bundy started killing when he was in a depressive funk, his life was not meeting the heights his narcissism was telling him it should be. He did not kill unemotionally, he killed in a rage, expressing his own pain. John Wayne Gacy, on the other hand, seems to be more of a "sociopath" (still scientifically APD), his lack of empathy was created by his abusive upbringing. So he was killing as an outlet for suppressed childhood pain, even if he may have been fairly unemotional while he was doing it. So I am wondering if Ben-Shahar gets this basic psychological understanding wrong, should we trust his advice? His ideas here are actually very good, if largely unoriginal, so it is a repetition of good advice thousands of years old. In particular he has created a good model to express it. It is just frustrating that a Harvard psychologist would be so inaccurate in his introduction.

This concept is borderline toxic positivity, mainly because the so called "antifragility" is based on the idea that growth is probable as a result of trauma, and that the trauma or stress we encounter is somehow the result of personal choices, which it isn't. The truth is that stress only results in positive growth when it is carefully curated and managed in controlled fashion, and the fact of the matter is that the vast majority of the stress we encounter isn't purely contrived. The only portion of this video I agree with is that happiness isn't something that can be sought with sole intention, and that people need genuine inspiration and motivation to accomplish something and happiness is a side effect of that achievement. Happiness also should not stem from delusional behaviors, or ideas, that separate one from objective truths dealing in socioemotional health.

Dont chase happiness because true happiness is  within you

Please bear with me here, while I set the context. The whole concept of right and wrong which are just value judgements based on our limited perception of reality, I like to think of them as lower and higher truths. That's where the whole 'Pursuit of Happiness' starts making less and less sense and becomes a lower truth when you enhance your perception.  Think about it, the concepts of happiness / sorrow ; pleasure / pain, exist in a relative world (which without doubt feel extremely real). But because when the scope of your happiness rises, so does the scope of sorrow, which means the happier you are, the more potential you have for sorrow (e.g. I bought my dream car and that makes the happiest i have ever been, but if some event were to take that car away from me, it would cause me immense suffering, may be even more than it made me happy).  So the idea is to keep enhancing your consciousness and perception and keep climbing from lower to higher truths until you transcend 'Happiness and Sorrow' or 'Pleasure and Pain'.

If for example my car breaks down and I have no money to fix it, I say "Thank you God for my car breaking down and I don't have the money to fix it and now I have no transportation to get to work". By expressing thanksgiving for the thing itself happening almost instantly that bad thing loses its negative effect on the psyche. The reason being the brain hears you express thanksgiving for that bad thing happening. It searches its database and remembers that when you say "thank you" it's because you received something good. Based on that pre-programming the brain then releases dopamine, the feel-good chemical that it is normally released when 'good' things happen to you. That's why the negative event no longer feels negative because the dopamine generated by you saying "thank you" neutralizes the negative emotion.

Wow, that's interesting! Probably takes a lot of composure, but it sounds like it ties into cognitive dissonance as well. If you are feeling sad but make yourself smile, your brain interprets the smile as you feeling happy and you actually feel happy. And once you are happy you're probably better prepared to tackle challenges you can't avoid rather than getting depressed about them.

Â @bigthinkÂ  I found out this 'trick' when my daughter died suddenly. She was my only daughter and I couldn't shake the grief. I mourned for months and it was destroying my will to live.  Then I read a Bible verse (no I am not religious but in my despair I tried everything) that said "For everything give God thanks". I noticed it didn't have a condition that the thanks is to be given only when something you interpret as being good happened to you. Obviously it took an incredible amount of emotional courage to say "Thank you God that my daughter is dead" because I feared that saying those words would make me feel evil.  But when I finally had the courage to utter them my mourning almost instantly evaporated. At that point it was as if her death was no longer a big deal. I still remember her fondly but I no longer mourned her from that moment. Not being a spiritual person I attributed it to what I described in my original post about the brain being tricked into thinking that something bad is something good by just saying thank you God for whatever it is that was bad.

Â @exoressdelivers70Â  ok so I did this when my mom died. So it may work for death since this world is cruel and our loved ones are better off not being here.  But what are the bounds to this â€œtrickâ€? Should an abuse victim thank god that sheâ€™s being punched everyday?

Â @CatMowpurrÂ  Yes. She is not being thankful she is being abused. She is negating the painful emotional and physical effect that the abuse has on her. Assuming she can't escape the abuse (maybe kidnapped and tied up in a dungeon) at least she will no longer feel the pain from the abuse. The alternative is to be abused and feel the pain from it.
Â @exoressdelivers70Â  so after the fact she can be thankful to trick her mind into being appreciative for a cruel world. What about during? Should she say thank you when sheâ€™s being punched?

Â @CatMowpurrÂ  I've never tried it while the bad activity was then and there going on. I only tried it after the ordeal was over when I felt sorrow, defeat, or emotional hurt and pain. It soothed me so that those emotions no longer had reign in my psyche. Instead I had peace instead. But there is absolutely nothing to lose by doing this and everything to gain. You can choose to stay in the emotional pain or come out of it by re-wiring your brain to believe that the pain is gone. It's your choice.

I was born disabled and became chronically ill at 12 years old, I am 22 now and have learned the hard way that life does not always get better, sometimes things somehow just get much worse, even with brute-force-positivity and countless nights of wishful thinking. I find the less that I specifically make time to validate myself, the more guilty, angry & confused I feel in life, for some reason we are taught that â€œvictimizing ourselvesâ€ is bad, but I think suppressing your true emotions is just detrimental. The more I acknowledge how bad my life is at times, the more I am able to also focus on the happy things I do have, it took me a long time to understand that some people need that balance! Strictly focusing on the positives isnâ€™t for everyone, especially when your basic needs canâ€™t be met. I definitely wouldnâ€™t say eating dark chocolate feels like a fair trade to being bed bound for weeks on end, but hey, the point is that I have finally learned to feel very thankful for the little things that bring me happiness. This was a lovely reminder that resilience looks different case to case

This! You are absolutely right, and you put that wonderfully. Sometimes reality is skewed and unfair, and not recognizing that only brings more trouble and paranoia. It takes a brave heart to see life as it is, and then to keep going without trying to sugarcoat it or find the silver line in everything. Life has its own worth regardless, and no one life is the same as another, so of course it's not helpful to compare and implement techniques or methods or schools of thought that were created by another for (and from) their own personal experience. It's good to get ideas, but ultimately to have your own unique sense of what is helping you and what isn't. And it's beautiful to find people that do, like yourself!

Your comment moved me to my core. You are brave and wise and self aware beyond your years. Though I don't even know you I feel such love for you, after reading your comment  I've done geriatric home health for a long time, so I know what it is to take care for people. To help them with even the most basic needs.   But that's so different really isn't it?!  You're a young person, who hasn't lived out a long life, free of normal unencumbrances.  In one fell swoop, you cut through the proverbial crap that we're fed about not thinking of ourselves as victims!!  Sometimes there isn't a bright side to look at, and as you stated, being able to stay positive all the damn time, isn't real.   Let any of us who are able-bodied try it for a while. Talk to us then and see how we feel, we'd be sniveling babies.  I want to reach right through my device and hug you tightly, and say nothing. For what could I say.  I don't have the first clue about what you go through, and you've heard all the words before.  I'm truly humbled.  Thank you!

The Antifragile system is not explained correctly, as in the book of Nassim Taleb. The example with the ball putting pressure on the surface explains better the Robust system, as Nassim describes in his book. The Fragile system would mean when the surface is broken. The Robust system would mean when after putting pressure, we get stronger. But Antifragile would mean when the ball is putting pressure, the surface may stay in the new shape, this way not breaking but also not becoming more robust either.

This is true; it can be a fine line, especially for people with mental disorders. That's one reason I believe things like this should be done with a therapist who knows you, sees you regularly, and can provide oversight and insight. Making Youtube videos and TED talks makes the messages more accessible, but have implicit risks.

â€‹Â @ThungStudiosÂ  Not everyone can afford a therapist though. I as a person with mental health diagnosis, prefer youtube videos and books over therapists, based on my personal experience with the therapists. Not saying they wanted to be bad nor that it was their fault that they couldn't help me most of the time, but.... a person has to take responsibility of their own mental health if they truly want to get to a better place, I strongly think.  Videos like these should have a disclaimer, because while the person presenting the information may have mental health credentials for all I know, it doesn't stop them from promoting fundamentally incomplete information, like they seem to do on this video

Wow, I have never seen so much black and white thinking is a video that purports to support mental health!   The banalized use of the word "trauma" is frankly shocking. It's almost like you are prescribing trauma as vitamins. First learn to distinguish between stress and trauma, perhaps? Trauma is the response of a person to an amount of stress they are not equipped to handle. When you are subjected to an amount of stress you can't handle, you lose control of your life and you as a person break down. Are you really saying that losing control of your life and breaking down is how people will learn to be happy? Are you out of your mind? Traumatized people are listening to your message in disbelief. This is incredibly invalidating to them.  I have been traumatized. I overcame it. I know exactly what happiness is, and after what I've been through, trust you me that I know how to appreciate every little bit of happiness. But it's a fight, because trauma makes it extremely difficult for a person to appreciate anything at all. When you are focusing on protecting yourself, you can't enjoy life. It's not because I overcame my trauma that I forgot about it. It's like you are suggesting that I should have, that bouncing back deletes that experience from your videotape. I lost everything because of my trauma, and there is no getting it back, and nothing that can replace what I lost. I can't try to have children again, I am too old now to have children, I am too old to adopt, and at this point it is too much work to even try to adopt. And here you are, telling me that having had this experience, which has taken from me things I will never have a chance to have again, was good for me?  I overcame my trauma, but I still remember it. Yeah, maybe it made me stronger as a person. But the cost of that strength is much too great, it is not a fair deal. If I had the choice between being this strong person and erasing my trauma, I would give up being this strong person to erase that trauma, to get to rewind my life and not have to have that experience. What you are saying about trauma being some kind of useful experience without which people can't learn to be happy is the biggest steaming pile of bull crap I have ever heard.  Challenging people by exposing them to hardships that they have to work themselves through, hardships that they do have the resources to overcome and do not overwhelm them, is not the same as exposing them to trauma. Your little theory is an insult to traumatized people.  I've really had it with pop psychology meant to sell books just to laugh all the way to the bank, at the expense of people who are not okay. Listen to some of your colleagues, especially the ones specialized in trauma. They disagree with you, and they are right. Your time would be better spent trying to teach people to not selfishly abuse others just because they don't value empathy. But of course, there is no money to be made in that, is there?

Â @doanale3344Â  We need to analyse the movie for my English class, so these are my interpretations.    - There was a scene where in blue memory ball Riley is sitting on a branch alone feeling sad because she lost the winning shot for her ice hockey team. And then her parents and teammates came and cheered her up, then she became happy as the memory ball turned golden (Sadness is a beacon; it signals our distress to others so they can help us)  - When Bing Bong lost his wagon in the abyss, Joy couldn't comfort him by saying it's not that bad, distracting him by tickling and forcing him to move on. Sadness on the other hand, sat down with him and got him to recall his adventures with Riley and validated how sad losing his only reminder of Riley is. Only then, after crying he could continue the journey. (Sadness is a core component of empathy - for us to be a good listener so others can vent to us and feel better. Also we need to make time for all our feelings, including Sadness. Avoiding our Sadness with distractions will only bottle it up inside and cause breakdowns/depression/lost of joy)  - Sadness caused Riley to act up in the movie, but in the end as Riley came home after her attempt to ran away, her relationship with her parents became stronger than ever. I can also recommend the cultivation of equanimity and some degree of inner calm and silence in the midst of life. These will greatly turn down the volume of our emotional reactivity, most of which is negative. These will transform the positive emotions into calmer and subtler versions of themselves. The calmer and subtler feelings are the more deeply they penetrate, and will therefore have greater power to endure and transform our lives. Think of these subtler mind states as waves. The waves on the ocean that are of low amplitude are very long. The example of the longest ocean wave is the tsunami that can be of very small height, but is so long that when it reaches the shore, it overwhelms the coast because it keeps on coming. In the same way, a few moments of deep beauty experienced in calm and inner silence, say for example watching a sunrise, can continue to echo in your heart all day long. Such moments can be recollected and cause our inner beings to ring with deep well being. On the other hand, if you try recollecting a more raucous moment of happiness, the afterglow is weaker and brief.  The calm, equanimous and silent mind has a kind of superpower; it can absorb and integrate within itself vast amounts of beauty and meaning.

I would agree happiness is on a continum, i would disagree that its a life long "journey". Only in that the word journey seems to feel like i start somewhere with happiness and end somewhere with it.  My happiness feeling hasn't changed. Its the same frequency its always been.  What has changed is how i do what i do. Which has "increased" the amount of time i can "tap in" to that continuum".  Like training for a job you love.  You start out happy but you don't know anything.  So, you experience quantifiable happiness in the form of, say, coffee before work. And that lasts 30 min. Then you go to work. Its new so its frustrating to not be doing it right at first. The learning process has its own kind of "happiness".  Then the next day and the next and the training becomes common knowledge.   Now not only are you happy for 30 minutes before work, but you feel happiness at work more often because learning the job, as frustrating as it was, affords HUGE SPANS of happiness due to practice.   Less stress because practice. Its honestly genius.  Anywho... So then the best part.  All the free time. Once you learn the dream job well, the happiness is doubled and the stress is reduced by half and the other half becomes positive stresses that actually encourage small growths of learning. Which increases the TIME happiness is able to be experienced.   Its a frequency.  A vibration. Like, its there all the time, its just knowing how to find it and use it wisely.

@Alice Amell mmm. You may have a fundamental misunderstanding of stoicism. The virtues important to the stoic are honor, honesty, courage (or lack of fear), determination to do the right thing, but never happiness. I'm not sure if happiness is a virtue, but for the stoic it is not even a goal. It is a by product of living a true life, a gift given to those who do not chase it.

@Alice Amell I don't know exactly what you mean by â€œ... following virtues.â€. But what I know is, stoicism is about accepting situations as they come, being unmoved by them and using them to make yourself a better person...just like gold gets refined in the fire. Stoicism encourages us to understand that life is not always upward or downward. Life is wavy. And we should see every circumstance as an opportunity to get better... especially the difficult circumstances. Stoicism teaches us to focus only on the things we can control and stop worrying about things out of our control. Epictetus once said â€œWho, then, is the invincible human being? One who can be disconcerted by nothing that lies outside the sphere of choice because the more we value things that are out of our control, the less control we have.â€  I think this goes in line with antifragility... which is about using difficult situations to get better.

Thank you for this presentation. Cultivating antifragility would be an alternative to materialism as a way of pursuing happiness.  By now we should realize material comforts and pursuits do not make us happy except perhaps to temporarily distract us from our unhappiness.  The following quote from Steps to Knowledge talks about finding happiness from the everyday simple experiences of life: 'You will find happiness in small things because happiness is with you. You will find happiness in small things because you are learning to be still and observant. You will find happiness in small things because your mind is becoming receptive. You will experience happiness in small things because you are being present to your current circumstances. Small things can carry great messages if you are attentive to them.' Learning to be still generates peace; peace, far from being passive, 'engages your life with great purpose and intensity, activating all of your powers and giving them uniform direction.' (quote & excerpts from Steps to Knowledge, Marshall Vian Summers)

There are painful emotions which Iâ€™m sure most people expect to experience, but then there are traumatic emotions which is a whole different thing. Traumatic emotions are something that a person was not psychologically ready to experience, something shocking. I think we often underestimate the effect of shock on human psychology. Analogy of this video only works for painful emotions, not traumatic. Painful emotions could be compared to weights that a person needs to lift to get the â€œmusclesâ€ stronger. Traumatic emotions however feel like you have to lift tons of weight which causes your â€œmusclesâ€ to tear apart. It feels like a huge rock fell on top of you completely unexpectedly. Thus a person with trauma cannot just become immediately stronger after such experience. They need healing time and sometimes lots of it to even just return to who they were before such experience

I think this perspective is important but i have to add that this is a view that comes from personality psychology. It is focused on traits and dispositions.  The SPIRE model does not tell us how to finde those parts. The emotional part for example. What exactly does it mean to also embrace painfull emotion? Many people with depressen tend to embrace sadness a bit too much, as the dvelve on past experiences of their life or on impossible futures they ought to get.  I believe there is more to it. Psychological flexibility is an important construct i got to know. This is a more cognitive and a more process orientated perspective to all that. I believe that the reasons why happiness is better to be searched indirectly are the self (ego) and the now. Pursuiing it directly puts a goal that is in the future and that can never be reached. Embracing a way of life that indirectly gives happiness will put you more in the "now". Directly chasing  happiness could also make you identify yourself as a person that still lacks happiness (why else would you search for it), which will affect how you see yourself and how you tell the story of your life to yourself.

Â @BiggyJimboÂ  When you say "detachment", it sounds like you're not letting yourself be in the moment. Like you're just clinging to the idea "this won't be forever" whenever anything happens. If that's so, that's not a good way to live. Buddhism, which this video gets most of its philosophy from, teaches that clinging to the way thing are - attachment - and being averse to the way things are - detachment - are the two root causes of human suffering. It teaches of a way in between those two things - nonattachment - not clinging on, but not avoiding either. It symbolizes these three states as two hands clasped firmly together, two hands held at a distance, and finally, two hands placed gently together with palms open. Rather than clinging firmly to the nature of change and using that idea as an anchor, you should hold on loosely to that idea and allow it to let you live fully in every moment.

Happiness is human flourishing and vice versa. To settle for less is to settle for less than human flourishing. Grit may be necessary, but there oughta be a way to mitigate it or defeat it with love, care, co-operation, and mutual respect. Settling for a hard life usually follows with an obsession with pain/testing the limits of how much you can do. Struggling for a good life is a contradiction in a just society. Settling for an unjust society is enabled by settling for an unforgiving world, which is enabled by a mindset that fragility is a vice, and not a response to something that needs to change. Anti-injustice is a better starting point, but a contradiction implies other ones. So, I guess anti-fragility is necessary in this fucked up world.

the trouble isn't valuing happiness, it's when you make happiness itself the goal. "i want to be happy" quite literally means you are not happy. it basically prevents you from being happy if you are constantly wanting to be happy, because by saying i want to be happy, you're actually saying i am not happy. that's just what the words mean.  and it goes in a circle. depressed, saying i wish i were happy, makes u depressed, so you say i wish i were happy, etc. doesn't matter where you start in the cycle, you end up in the same places i think.  that's not to say all depression is simply due to specifically seeking happiness directly, but ongoing depression that you don't bounce back from is perhaps due to the cycle of unintentionally telling yourself you're not happy?  it was only mentioned for a moment, but taking the time to be thankful for what little you may have is pretty powerful if you can get into the habit. the feeling of thankfulness is akin to contentedness, which in my mind is a plenty good place to be/work from.

There's no antifragile. The mind can get stronger, bigger, but it is still mind and can be fragile.  In Ananda Marga we say that the mind develops through "clash and cohesion", which is basically the same as the "post traumatic growth" mentioned in the video. But we (mostly) don't look for clash, physical or emotional, or trauma(!), but it comes naturally. And for us spirituality not just "finding meaning and purpose", but it is a practical thing, well explained in our philosophy. As "spirit" or "consciousness" is perfect in itself, spirituality essentially means the psycho-spiritual process or sadhana or tantrik meditation where we direct our mind inwards, towards consciousness. That results in a very profoundly healing, cohesive process, which at the same time incites more clashes or sources of unhappiness on our way! That also gives balance and perspective to the sources or happiness and unhappiness in our lives. And sadhana and helping others selflessly are the best way to make the mind stronger.

I would refer to this as "PTG training" or "antifragility training". The idea is to grow your resilience and toughness by exposing yourself to progressive levels of trauma that you can handle in a relatively controlled environment. There are certain sports or physical activities which I think contribute to PTG, by being extremely challenging or demanding, even painful, without risking your health. Professional guidance and adequate physical preparation are fundamental, but there is a lot that comes from within yourself, which I think has a lot to do with your happiness skills.  The first one I can think of is rock climbing. You can start at a very easy level which almost everybody can try, but it always takes you to situations which appear impossible to overcome. Only by trying and trying again, defeating your frustration and improving yourself, you come to realize that you can actually do things that you thought were impossible.  Hiking and mountain-biking add some elements of risk. You can get injured for real and experience real pain. So it is especially important to be properly equipped and trained at your level. Being able to get back on the bike after a fall is as close as I can imagine to PTG. I should just insist this is not about being reckless. You really have to be disciplined to work at your level and avoid unnecessary risks that can hamper your progress.  Playing the guitar, as harmless as it is, can be quite frustrating and painful. Your fingers really hurt and the retribuition of playing well takes a lot of practice and patience.  You may come with similar explanations for other sports or activities, such as tennis or golf. From these examples it appears that the primary area of action is Physical, then Emotional. It's hard to imagine a connection with the other three, but there must be ways to work on those too.

For me, when quitting smoking back in 2002, and then quitting drinking in 2020, it involved learning to examine and embrace my entire spectrum of emotions and feelings unafraid. Even unlearning to label them as negative is really key, because labeling as negative causes avoidance and pain. There are times when we can consciously decide that a given line of inner dialogue or self-representation is unproductive, and that's good for us, but there are other times when we reactively reject the examination of a state of inner turmoil or pain and if we only thought to investigate further, we might find it contained hidden gems â€” that it contains its own cure.

Exercise is huge. Especially exercise that continually explores new ways of moving and developing mobility, strength, and flexibility along previously untried lines. The physical development creates mental and emotional analogues.

Live life as it comes upon you, do what you need to do and still to a routine to survive.  Pursue the most optimal routine for all of your goals and don't get attached.  Continue on your road towards your goals and don't look to past to long for things that are gone.   The past is gone and cannot be changed, the present is what will make the future a better time to be alive.   Grow through the challenges of existence, work and do everything as if you were already dead, as if everything had been already been lost.   Work as if your dreams are unattainable and work to achieve them all the same, work as if you had failed already and still worry more about becoming a better you rather than worrying about how you will deal with the future, deal with the present and focus on that.   Keep yourself as busy as possible and keep good relationships with people, hold yourself accountable for everything you do or don't.   Do more than it is necessary, it is never enough.   Work yourself to dead and pursue that which you want to achieve relentlessly never stopping.   Dedicate your present life to what you want your future to be, don't let yourself doubt about being able to achieve it or not, that's why you must work as if it was possible but expect nothing in return because it is already something you lost and can never get back.   This mindset will make you focus on becoming the person who could be X, even if attaining X is impossible now, this will make become the ideal you and if things do work out for you in the end then that will make it all the better.  Worst case scenario you end becoming who wanted to be in a place where you shouldn't be.  The logic is that when you are that person that should be at X place, then people will acknowledge you and society as well, at some point you will be able to reach out to X dream and make it a reality, because you already became the ideal person to make X a reality.

Â @AO-wg9neÂ  you'll see different translations, but one way to think of it is "unsatisfactoriness." We're almost always wanting something, worrying about something, wishing we could change or improve something. It's like the wheel of a cart being slightly out of joint. We're always trying to get comfortable, always trying to get lasting satisfaction, and there's none to be had.  If we're lucky enough not to be experiencing acute suffering right now, and even if we're lucky enough to live a long time, it's unavoidable that we will undergo illness, old age, separation from the people we care about, and death.  Buddhists feel that it's best not to ignore or try to run away from these truths, because that only causes MORE suffering. We accept them fully and give our time and energy to what we really care about in the present moment.

Â @oldnatty61Â  I'm afraid you're misunderstanding the concept. Anti-fragility means that certain systems require regular exposure to stress in order to grow stronger and achieve their full potential. Bone and muscle, for example, increase in strength and resilience by being exercised, that is, stressed. Bone becomes denser, muscles tear in working out but grow back stronger with increased mass and power. The same principle holds true psychologically, and is the foundation of cognitive behavioral therapy in which measured exposure to sources of emotional stress leads inevitably to greater resilience and psychological strength.

As a Buddhist, I want to elaborate more about Buddhist's Dukkha: Dukkha as a part of 4 noble truths (Cattari Ariya Saccani) is comprised of:  1. Common suffering (Dukkha-dukkha), having common cold, stomacache, toothache, etc  2. Pain caused by impermanence (Viparinama-Dukkha): losing/be separated from the one you love, meeting/gather with the one you hate, not achieving your aspirations  3. Suffering as a consequence of having a physical body (Sankhara-Dukkha): Old age, sickness, death  And these suffering comes from unending thirst (Tanha) of worldly pleasures/desires and Avijja/ignorance or misconception of the noble truths that caused Kilesa (defilement/darkness of the mind) which are:  1. Lobha (Greed, craving for more) 2. Dosa (Hate, wishing bad things happen to others) 3. Moha (Not able to differentiate whether an act is right or wrong, having a wrong view of the world)  (There is still so many derivatives of the kilesa I wont explain here)

@eminayidenÂ ,  "The first Truth is 'All is suffering.' First of all, as a belief itâ€™s false because suffering is a comparative term and comparative terms canâ€™t be extended to everything. 'Itâ€™d be like saying everything is tall.' It really means something more like 'All is threatened by'.  Suffering now means something like â€˜painâ€™ or â€˜distressâ€™ but thatâ€™s not really what the word originally (or etymologically) means. Suffering means â€˜to undergo.â€™ To lose agency. So you can actually suffer joy â€” experience so much joy you lose control of yourself. (Pain is certainly one common way of losing agency â€” itâ€™s very disruptive, usually preceded by damage â€” which is probably why our current sense of the word aligns more to that example.) So the Buddha isnâ€™t saying 'everything is painful.'  Most of the Buddhaâ€™s metaphors arenâ€™t pain metaphors theyâ€™re entrapment metaphors. Being fettered. Losing your freedom. Losing your agency.  The Buddha has famously said: 'Just like wherever you dip into the ocean it has one taste, the taste of salt, no matter where you dip into my teaching it has one taste, the taste of freedom.' So with this Truth heâ€™s saying something more like: 'realize that all of your life is threatened with the loss of freedom, the loss of agency.' The word for this type of loss is dukkha."  - John Vervaeke, Ep. 13 â€” Buddhism and Parasitic Processing

I have 4 dogs and a lot of house plants which is remarkable because I by far did not get my dads green thumb . I kill plants always have . but now that I am seeing myself in them as I car for them I see a remarkable process . I check there growth what do the leaves look like so I can trim the dieing and keep it from putting resources into dieing and put it into the new and healthy . I am a part of its way of living and it is a part of mine I now see myself as a person and the house plant . I am accessing my leaves and taking out the dead so to help the full plant I am to build a beautiful plant with purples and greens that makes my eyes pop . Â @gojiberry7201Â  Great - I'm a big fan of DBT, and not just for it's original indication.  I've found it quite helpful.

Â @HolisticDramaFreeÂ  I know there are a variety of different groups, but it probably depends on the area. Dialectical Behavorial Therapy (DBT) is pretty specific, and it was originally designed to help people with BPD (Borderline Personality Disorder), but I don't have BPD and it's helping me a lot. There might be online groups as well. It's getting more mainstream, and one thing our teacher says is that it's life skills that everyone should really know. It's about emotional regulation, mindfulness, and communication. I also go to one-on-one therapy for talking about personal trauma and issues. Good luck to you!

This appears to be the study referenced: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29545165/  It seems to be a trait-level study: people with more curious personalities and practices have longer lifespans. So while inevitably we sometimes find unsatisfying answers to questions we are curious about, those individual moments are probably too small to attach to a significant change in lifespan. It's more a pattern of actions which will turn up pleasing as well as displeasing answers, and the mental exercise of pursuing them--in the same way that running a race can be beneficial to our health whether or not we are happy with our result.
